did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.unittitle: Willard B. Golovin papers 1882-1974 and undated
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Artist, advertising executive (Willard B. Golovin Co.) and director of an art gallery (Bayer Gallery) in New York, N.Y.

Collection spans the years 1882-1974 and includes correspondence, tear sheets, clippings, printed material and original artwork that document Golovin's careers running the Willard B. Golovin agency and the Bayer Gallery. Clients include Aberle, Frances Denney, Glen Guard clothiers, and Harry Winston jewelers. There are also files relating to support efforts during World War II and a series of posters addressing absenteeism in war work industries. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.Cataloged from inventory.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Willard B. Golovin Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Willard B. Golovin Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2012.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accession 2012-0260 is described in this finding aid.
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and local Style Guide.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection spans the years 1882-1974 and includes correspondence, tear sheets, clippings, printed material and original artwork that document Golovin's careers running the Willard B. Golovin agency and the Bayer Gallery. Clients include Aberle, Frances Denney, Glen Guard clothiers, and Harry Winston jewelers. There are also files relating to support efforts during World War II and a series of posters addressing absenteeism in war work industries.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: Personal and General Files; Agency Files; Financial Records; Advertisements; and Large-Format Materials. Where possible or practical, original folder titles were maintained.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

No.1: They had but one life to give! You have every day
No.3: Inaccurate typing may mean mistakes at the front
No.4: You can't beat A. Hitler in here (bathroom)
No.6: Every minute you are late holds back our fate--Hitler and Hirohito
No.7: Your absence has his blessing--Keep in good health to keep on the job (Hitler as angel)
No.8: Let your conscience be your guide--Stay on the job--Help America win
No.9: Absence makes Hitler's heart grow fonder--keep in good health to keep on the job
No.10: There's a mistake somewhere--Concentrate on your job--Errors are serious
No.11: Your typewriter may produce the margin for victory--Stay on the job--Every hour every day!
No.12: Don't daydream--Your work is vital to victory
No.13: Make them happy (Hitler and Hirohito)--Takes lots of time out
No.15: You can't beat the Axis in here! (break room)--Stay on the job--Every hour every day!
